awd_titl_txt: Student Pathways Opening World Energy Resources (S-POWER)
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed program addresses two national crises: (i) the extremely low persistence rate of underrepresented minority (URM) transfer students to bachelor degree granting institutions in STEM fields, and (ii) the need for fundamental research and training in energy related fields. Through the awarding of scholarship support to low-income, academically talented students, and by designing, implementing, assessing, and disseminating essential new approaches to transfer student education, S-POWER will unite students and faculty at both sending and receiving institutions to collaboratively address Grand Energy challenges, such as developing materials for energy efficient systems and energy power management. 

To implement the above vision, the investigators will create project-specific teams of faculty and students to build social and mentoring ties and enable focused educational support structures, including formal mentoring with industry and implementation of shared educational pedagogies at both the sending and receiving institutions. This departs from most traditional transfer student educational processes in which it is only the sender or receiving institution's responsibility to educate the student attending each institution. In addition, S-POWER will study and document additional barriers for URM transfer students, while investigating the similarities and differences of experiences for students that begin their academic journey in four-year versus community colleges. The success of the S-POWER educational pedagogy will be assessed throughout each student's educational career, and factors that positively influence transfer student success will be disseminated to the broader educational community.

por.por_cntn:
Student-Pathways Opening World Energy Resources (S-POWER), active from 09/15/2016 to 08/31/2023, aimed to revolutionize the educational approach for transfer students, particularly focusing on financially needy, underrepresented minority (URM), female, socio-economically disadvantaged, and first-generation students. Northeastern University (NU), serving as the leading institution and the receiving entity for the program, collaborated with institutions such as Clark-Atlanta University (CAU), three Regional Community Colleges (RCCs) in Boston, and Hampton University (HU). The program sought to establish seamless transfer infrastructures, integrate cross-institutional mentoring, and provide early exposure to energy-related research.

S-POWER built cross-institutional social and professional cohorts between faculty and students, unified by their motivation to solve Grand Energy Challenges within engineering. 229 total S-POWER students were financially supported by scholarships at both sending and receiving institutions.  Over a dozen faculty participated in S-POWER participating in student advising and mentoring, faculty-faculty mentoring, curriculum sharing and reform in addition to the development of specific recruitment and retention strategies. A defining component of S-POWER is the requirement that advising and mentoring will occur at both the sending and receiving institutions simultaneously and throughout the S-POWER scholar’s entire career.

Intellectual Merit: The S-POWER program successfully streamlined the transfer process, fostering faculty interactions between sending and receiving institutions. Faculty from Northeastern University engaged with students at sending institutions, providing lectures, running labs, and offering academic career advice. The meticulous review of syllabi for engineering and STEM courses ensured a smoother acceptance process by NU's Admissions office. This intellectual merit is reflected in the enhanced faculty-faculty interaction, course revisions at sending institutions, and the introduction of new lab offerings and short courses on clean energy.

Broader Impacts: The S-POWER program made substantial contributions to the educational and research landscape. Beyond the academic realm, the program revealed a key outcome: the significance of two crucial elements in the Scholar's success. First, the support of a cohort of students played a pivotal role, providing a sense of community and shared experiences. Second, establishing a connection with one of the mentoring faculty or staff members proved instrumental in the academic and personal development of the Scholars. Beyond the academic realm, the program fostered a sense of community through bi-weekly cohort meetings, networking events, and academic supports such as peer tutoring. The Summer Bridge program expanded on the NU campus, inviting all URM students in Engineering and the College of Science to academic and mentoring workshops. The Undergraduate Research Fair provided a platform for students to connect with faculty from various colleges offering research opportunities. These broader impacts are evident in the program's resilience during the Covid period, with continued research engagement and virtual events.

Specific video testimonies of the impact of the S-POWER program are available to the public and can be found at: https://web.northeastern.edu/spower/

In summary, the S-POWER Scholarship Program showcased that, with the implementation of proper financial and mentoring support at Northeastern University (the receiving institution), transfer students, particularly those from underrepresented minority (URM) and financially needy backgrounds, not only performed academically on par with other NU students but also experienced a transformative sense of belonging and mentorship. Out of the 229 students financially supported by S-POWER, 95 decided to attend Northeastern University. These NU students showcased a remarkable annual retention rate regularly above 95%. This tailored success is manifested in comparable GPA, retention rates, and job placement outcomes compared to other NU students. In conclusion, the program has not only met its primary goals but exceeded expectations, unveiling key insights into the crucial factors that contribute to the success of targeted transfer students in the clean energy-related field.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2024
Modified by: Bradley M Lehman
